questions.text: In Worth four dot test, the patient’s perception is shown in the image below. What would be the interpretation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Orthophoria

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Right Suppression : A person with suppression of the right eye will see only two green dots because the right eye (covered by the red lens) suppresses the red dot, and the white dot appears green through the green lens of the left eye.

  • • Right Suppression
  • • suppression of the right eye will see only two green dots because the right eye
  • • Option B. Left Suppression : A person with suppression of the left eye will see three dots - two green and one red . The left eye (covered by the green lens) suppresses the green dots, and the white dot appears red through the red lens of the right eye.
  • • Option B.
  • • Left Suppression
  • • left eye will see three dots - two green and one red
  • • Option D. Diplopia : If the person has double vision (diplopia), they will see five dots - three green (two from the right eye and one white dot seen as green by the left eye) and two red (one from the left eye and one white dot seen as red by the right eye).

  • • Diplopia
  • • person has double vision
  • • will see five dots

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Worth Four Dot Test results vary based on the patient's visual condition : right suppression shows two green dots , left suppression shows two green and one red dot , orthophoria shows two green , one red , and one combined dot , and diplopia shows three green and two red dots.

  • • controls most of the extraocular muscles of the left eye
  • • Option D . Left Abducent Nerve (Cranial Nerve VI): The lateral rectus muscle of the left eye is innervated by the left abducent nerve .

questions.text: Amongst the following cranial nerves, which nerve supplies the longest extraocular muscle?

These muscles are involved in moving the eye medially, downwards, and in extorsion and elevation (inferior oblique), respectively.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant with cerebral palsy is brought in by her mother due to a recent onset of eye deviation. The mother reports that the deviation is more noticeable when the child is focusing on objects. The child has no history of trauma, infection, and is up-to-date with vaccinations. During the physical examination, you note that the child's eyes do not align properly, especially in lateral gaze. Based on this presentation, which of the following is the most likely characteristic of this child's strabismus?

options.label: B
options.text: Onset is within 2 years of age

options.label: C
options.text: Cross fixation in side gaze noted

questions.correct_answer: C. Cross fixation in side gaze noted
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cross fixation in side gaze noted

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Small Angle of Squint: Early onset esotropia often presents with a large angle of squint rather than a small one.
  • • Option A
  • • Small Angle of Squint:
  • • Early onset esotropia
  • • large angle of squint
  • • Option B. Onset is Within 2 Years of Age: Early onset esotropia, as the name suggests, typically begins in infancy or early childhood. The most common form , congenital or infantile esotropia , often appears before the child reaches 6 months of age.
  • • Option B.
  • • Onset is Within 2 Years of Age:
  • • begins in infancy or early childhood.
  • • most common form
  • • congenital or infantile esotropia
  • • Option D. Presence of Significant Refractive Error: While refractive errors can be associated with some forms of strabismus , early onset esotropia is not typically characterized by significant refractive errors.
  • • Option D.
  • • Presence of Significant Refractive Error:
  • • refractive errors can be associated with some forms of strabismus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize that early onset esotropia typically presents within the first two years of life , often with large-angle squint and cross fixation behavior , but not necessarily with significant refractive errors.
  • ➤ Recognize that early onset esotropia
  • ➤ presents within the first two years of life
  • ➤ large-angle squint
  • ➤ cross fixation behavior

  • ➤ Ref

questions.text: Based on the test finding given below, what would the diagnosis be?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Esophoria

  • • Option B. Orthophoria:
  • • Option

  • • Findings

  • • Interpretation : The displacement of the line to the right indicates a tendency for the covered eye to turn outward , characteristic of exophoria.

  • • Option D. Hypophoria:

When the Maddox Rod is placed horizontally in front of one eye, the patient with hypophoria will see the line displaced either above or below the light, depending on which eye is covered and the direction of the deviation.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with squint was undergoing corrective surgery. Heart rate recorded prior to initiation was 100 bpm. After anaesthesia and start of surgery, heart rate reduced to 50 bpm. How to intervene further?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Administer Inj. Atropine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Increase the dose of anesthesia :
  • • Option A.
  • • Increase the dose of anesthesia
  • • Increasing the dose of anesthesia in the case of bradycardia is generally not advisable . Many anesthetics can depress myocardial function and further reduce heart rate. This action could exacerbate the situation rather than alleviate it.
  • • case of bradycardia is generally not advisable
  • • Option B. Administer beta blockers :
  • • Option B.
  • • Administer beta blockers
  • • Beta blockers are contraindicated in this situation. They are typically used to decrease heart rate and blood pressure. Administering beta blockers to a patient who is already experiencing bradycardia could be dangerous, as it could further lower the heart rate, potentially leading to hemodynamic instability.
  • • typically used to decrease heart rate and blood pressure.
  • • Option C . Cessation of surgery :
  • • Option C
  • • Cessation of surgery
  • • While it is important to always be prepared to stop surgery if the patient's condition deteriorates significantly, immediate cessation of surgery for bradycardia is not always necessary. The cause of the bradycardia should be identified and treated accordingly. If the bradycardia is directly related to the surgical procedure or anesthesia, then pausing might be considered while corrective measures are taken.
  • • prepared to stop surgery if the patient's condition deteriorates significantly,
  • • cessation of surgery for bradycardia is not always necessary.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the case of a significant reduction in heart rate to 50 bpm in a child during surgery, the appropriate intervention is to administer Inj. Atropine. This acts to increase heart rate by antagonizing the vagal effects on the heart , and is a critical response in managing oculocardiac reflex during squint surgery.
  • ➤ reduction in heart rate to 50 bpm in a child during surgery,
  • ➤ intervention is to administer Inj. Atropine.
  • ➤ increase heart rate by antagonizing the vagal effects on the heart
  • ➤ Ref : AAO SECTION:6 – PAEDIATRIC OPHTHALMOLOGY AND STRABISMUS. PG.NO: 174
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : AAO SECTION:6 – PAEDIATRIC OPHTHALMOLOGY AND STRABISMUS. PG.NO: 174

questions.text: Based on the evaluation of a patient with strabismus, a 15º primary deviation and 30º secondary deviation were recorded. What type of strabismus does this indicate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Paralytic squint

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Concomitant Squint :
  • • Option A.
  • • Concomitant Squint
  • • In concomitant squint (also known as non-paralytic or comitant squint), the degree of deviation remains constant regardless of the direction of gaze . It means that the angle of misalignment does not change when the patient looks in different directions.
  • • concomitant squint
  • • degree of deviation remains constant regardless of the direction of gaze
  • • Primary deviation = Secondary deviation.
  • • Option B. Accommodative Esotropia :
  • • Option B.
  • • Accommodative Esotropia
  • • Accommodative esotropia is a type of concomitant squint where the eyes turn inward . It is often related to uncorrected hyperopia and the eye's effort to accommodate leads to convergence and thus inward turning of the eyes . Like other forms of concomitant squint, the primary and secondary deviations in accommodative esotropia are equal.
  • • concomitant squint where the eyes turn inward
  • • uncorrected hyperopia
  • • eye's effort to accommodate leads to convergence
  • • inward turning of the eyes
  • • Option D. Convergence Insufficiency :
  • • Option D.
  • • Convergence Insufficiency
  • • Convergence insufficiency is a condition where the eyes do not work together well while focusing on a near object . The eyes have difficulty converging adequately for near work , leading to symptoms like eyestrain and blurring - asthenopia. It does not typically present with a difference between primary and secondary deviations.
  • • eyes do not work together well while focusing on a near object
  • • difficulty converging adequately for near work

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a case with a 15º primary deviation and a 30º secondary deviation in strabismus , the diagnosis is indicative of a paralytic squint . This finding is characteristic of paralytic strabismus , where the secondary deviation (when the affected eye is fixating) is greater than the primary deviation (when the unaffected eye is fixating), reflecting the impact of muscle weakness or paralysis.
  • ➤ 15º primary deviation and a 30º secondary deviation in strabismus
  • ➤ indicative of a paralytic squint
  • ➤ characteristic of paralytic strabismus
  • ➤ secondary deviation
  • ➤ greater than the primary deviation

questions.text: When we fix our visual attention on an object of regard, the image is formed on the fovea of both our eyes separately; but we perceive a single image. Which of the following is not a component of this state of binocular single vision?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fixation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Fusion :
  • • Option A.
  • • Fusion
  • • Fusion is a key component of binocular single vision . It is the process by which the brain combines the two slightly different images received from each eye into a single , unified image. This is crucial for achieving binocular single vision.
  • • binocular single vision
  • • process by which the brain combines the two slightly different images received from each eye into a single
  • • Option B . Simultaneous Perception :
  • • Option B
  • • Simultaneous Perception
  • • Simultaneous perception is also an essential component of binocular single vision . It refers to the ability of the visual system to perceive images presented to each eye simultaneously, which is a prerequisite for fusion to occur.
  • • essential component of binocular single vision
  • • ability of the visual system to perceive images presented to each eye
  • • Option D. Stereopsis :
  • • Option D.
  • • Stereopsis
  • • Stereopsis is the perception of depth that arises from the brain's processing of the slightly different images from each eye . It is a higher-level outcome of binocular single vision, but not a fundamental component of achieving binocular single vision itself. Stereopsis is dependent on the successful integration of the other components (fusion and simultaneous perception).
  • • perception of depth that arises from the brain's processing of the slightly different images from each eye

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the context of binocular single vision , fixation is not a component specific to this state.

questions.text: A child was brought to the ophthalmologist with complaint of inability to look up.   • • Optin D. Edinger-Westphal Nucleus : The Edinger-Westphal nucleus is part of the oculomotor nuclear complex and is primarily associated with the parasympathetic control of the eye , contributing to pupillary constriction and accommodation, rather than eye movements.

questions.text: All are true statements regarding the sequelae of extraocular muscle palsy except:
questions.explanation:

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Contracture of Direct Antagonist : This statement is true . In cases of chronic extraocular muscle palsy, the direct antagonist can undergo contracture due to prolonged unopposed action.
  • • Option A
  • • Contracture of Direct Antagonist
  • • true
  • • Option C . Overaction of Direct Antagonist : This statement is true . The direct antagonist (the muscle that opposes the action of the paralyzed muscle in the same eye) overacts in response to muscle palsy because it is no longer being counteracted by the paralyzed muscle.
  • • Option C
  • • Overaction of Direct Antagonist
  • • true
  • • Option D. Inhibitional Palsy of Contralateral Antagonist : This statement is also true . Inhibitional palsy of the contralateral antagonist is a phenomenon observed in extraocular muscle palsy, where the antagonist of the paralyzed muscle in the opposite eye shows underaction.
  • • Option D.
  • • Inhibitional Palsy of Contralateral Antagonist
  • • true
  • • Due to unopposed overaction of ipsilateral antagonist, there is reduced innervation of its yolk muscle, i.e. the contralateral antagonist of the paralysed muscle, following Hering’s law. This leads to a pseudoparesis of the contralateral antagonist in the early stages.

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient came to the OPD with a complaint of double vision since few months which was worse for distant objects. The patient gave a history of deviation of one eye since childhood. On examination,right esotropia was noted and after further evaluation, a diagnosis of right lateral rectus palsy was made. What is the ideal surgical procedure for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Recession of right lateral rectus and medial rectus

options.label: B
options.text: Resection of right lateral rectus and medial rectus

options.label: C
options.text: Resection of right lateral rectus and recession of right medial rectus

options.label: D
options.text: Recession of right lateral rectus and resection of right medial rectus

questions.correct_answer: C. Resection of right lateral rectus and recession of right medial rectus
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Resection of right lateral rectus and recession of right medial rectus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Recession of right lateral rectus and medial rectus: This would not be ideal for lateral rectus palsy . Recession (weakening) of the already palsied lateral rectus would exacerbate the problem , and recessing the medial rectus of the same eye could lead to significant imbalance.
  • • Option A.
  • • Recession of right lateral rectus and medial rectus:
  • • not be ideal for lateral rectus palsy
  • • Recession
  • • already palsied lateral rectus
  • • exacerbate the problem
  • • Option B. Resection of right lateral rectus and medial rectus : Resecting (shortening/strengthening) the palsied lateral rectus might be considered , but resecting the medial rectus in the same eye typically would not be indicated as it would further imbalance the eye.
  • • Option B.
  • • Resection of right lateral rectus and medial rectus
  • • palsied lateral rectus might be considered
  • • resecting the medial rectus in the same eye typically would not be indicated
  • • Option D. Recession of right lateral rectus and resection of right medial rectus : Recession (weakening) of a palsied muscle and resection (strengthening) of its antagonist will worsen the squint and the diplopia in this case.
  • • Option D.
  • • Recession of right lateral rectus and resection of right medial rectus
  • • Recession
  • • palsied muscle and resection
  • • antagonist will worsen the squint

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient with right lateral rectus palsy , the ideal surgical intervention typically involves resecting (strengthening) the weak right lateral rectus and recessing (weakening) the opposing right medial rectus to restore ocular balance and alignment .
  • ➤ patient with right lateral rectus palsy
  • ➤ ideal surgical intervention typically involves resecting
  • ➤ weak right lateral rectus and recessing
  • ➤ opposing right medial rectus
  • ➤ restore ocular balance
  • ➤ alignment
  • ➤ Ref : KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5 TH EDITION pg.no: 354
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5 TH EDITION pg.no: 354

questions.text: Identify the pattern of deviation:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A pattern esotropia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. V pattern esotropia : A type of strabismus where the inward deviation of the eyes (esotropia) increases when looking upwards as compared to looking downwards.
  • • Option B.
  • • V pattern esotropia
  • • type of strabismus where the inward deviation of the eyes
  • • increases when looking upwards
  • • Option C. A pattern exotropia: A form of strabismus where the outward turning of the eyes (exotropia) becomes more pronounced when the eyes are directed downwards compared to upwards.
  • • Option C.
  • • A pattern exotropia:
  • • strabismus where the outward turning of the eyes
  • • becomes more pronounced
  • • eyes are directed downwards
  • • Option D. V pattern exotropia : A strabismus condition characterized by an increase in the outward deviation of the eyes (exotropia) when looking upwards as compared to looking downwards.
  • • Option D.
  • • V pattern exotropia
  • • strabismus condition characterized by an increase in the outward deviation of the eyes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ “A” pattern esotropia is a strabismic condition where the esotropia is more pronounced when the eyes are directed downwards compared to upwards.
  • ➤ Ref : KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5 TH EDITION pg.no: 355

questions.text: All are true regarding penalization except:

options.label: D
options.text: It is a treatment option for amblyopia

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Done in squinting eye

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Useful in very young children : This is true . Penalization is often used in young children as a treatment for amblyopia, especially when patching therapy is not feasible or not tolerated.
  • • Option A.
  • • Useful in very young children
  • • true
  • • Option C. This procedure uses atropine: True . Atropine is used in penalization therapy to blur the vision in the non-amblyopic eye by dilating the pupil and paralyzing the accommodation, thereby forcing the amblyopic eye to work harder and improve.
  • • Option C.
  • • This procedure uses atropine: True
  • • Option D. It is a treatment option for amblyopia: True . Penalization is a well-recognized treatment option for amblyopia, particularly in cases where traditional patching is not suitable or effective.
  • • Option D.
  • • It is a treatment option for amblyopia: True

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Penalization therapy for amblyopia involves applying atropine to the non-amblyopic (non-squinting) eye to blur its vision and stimulate use of the amblyopic (squinting) eye , making it an effective treatment in very young children.
  • ➤ Penalization therapy for amblyopia involves applying atropine to the non-amblyopic
  • ➤ eye to blur its vision
  • ➤ stimulate use of the amblyopic
  • ➤ eye

The test determines whether the patient has bifoveal fixation or monofixation despite their eyes seeming straight.

questions.text: Identify the given scenario:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dissociated vertical deviation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Acquired Skew Deviation : A neurological disorder characterized by vertical misalignment of the eyes due to disruption of vestibular or brainstem pathways, often associated with brain lesions or injuries.
  • • Option A.
  • • Acquired Skew Deviation
  • • neurological disorder characterized by vertical misalignment of the eyes
  • • Option B. Superior Oblique Palsy : A condition caused by weakness or paralysis of the superior oblique muscle , leading to vertical diplopia (double vision), head tilt, and difficulty with downward gaze, especially when looking towards the nose.
  • • Option B.
  • • Superior Oblique Palsy
  • • weakness or paralysis of the superior oblique muscle
  • • vertical diplopia
  • • Option D. Superior Oblique Overaction: A condition where the superior oblique muscle is overactive , leading to excessive inward and downward movement of the eye , often causing a V-pattern strabismus and tilting of images.
  • • Option D.
  • • Superior Oblique Overaction:
  • • superior oblique muscle is overactive
  • • excessive inward and downward movement of the eye

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dissociated Vertical Deviation (DVD) is a unique type of strabismus where one eye drifts upward when the other eye is fixating , often seen in patients with a history of congenital or early-onset strabismus.
  • ➤ Dissociated Vertical Deviation

  • ➤ one eye drifts upward
  • ➤ other eye is fixating

questions.text: The following images are taken after asking the patient to look up and right, straight up and up and left. Identify the condition:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Double elevator palsy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Superior Oblique Palsy : A condition characterized by weakness or paralysis of the superior oblique muscle , leading to vertical and torsional double vision , often accompanied by a compensatory head tilt.
  • • Option A.
  • • Superior Oblique Palsy
  • • weakness or paralysis of the superior oblique muscle
  • • vertical and torsional double vision
  • • Option B. Möbius Syndrome : A rare congenital disorder characterized by facial paralysis and abducens nerve palsy , resulting in limited facial expression and lateral gaze palsy.
  • • Option B.
  • • Möbius Syndrome
  • • congenital disorder
  • • facial paralysis and abducens nerve palsy
  • • limited facial expression
  • • Option D. Brown Syndrome : A disorder characterized by a restriction in the movement of the superior oblique tendon , resulting in difficulty elevating the affected eye , particularly in adduction.
  • • Option D.
  • • Brown Syndrome
  • • restriction in the movement of the superior oblique tendon
  • • difficulty elevating the affected eye

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Double Elevator Palsy is rare condition where there is a limitation of elevation in one eye , thought to be due to a palsy of both the superior rectus and the inferior oblique muscles .

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presented with complaints of defective vision. His best corrected visual acuity in right eye was 6/6 and in left eye was 6/60. Retinoscopy revealed +1D in right eye and +7D in left eye. Ocular examination was within normal limits. The probable diagnosis would be?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Amblyopia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Malingering: This would imply the patient is feigning or exaggerating the extent of visual impairment . However, the significant difference in refractive error between the eyes and the corresponding difference in visual acuity suggest a genuine visual problem, making malingering unlikely.
  • • Option A.
  • • Malingering:
  • • patient is feigning or exaggerating the extent of visual impairment
  • • Option C. Retrobulbar Neuritis : This condition typically presents with pain on eye movement and a rapid reduction in visual acuity , often associated with color vision impairment . There's no indication of these symptoms from the given information.
  • • Option C.
  • • Retrobulbar Neuritis
  • • presents with pain on eye movement and a rapid reduction in visual acuity
  • • color vision impairment
  • • Option D. Refractive Accommodative Esotropia : This condition is characterized by esotropia (inward turning of the eye) that is caused primarily by uncorrected hyperopia (farsightedness). While the patient has hyperopia in the left eye, there's no mention of esotropia.
  • • Option D.
  • • Refractive Accommodative Esotropia
  • • characterized by esotropia
  • • caused primarily by uncorrected hyperopia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most probable diagnosis in this case is amblyopia , likely anisometropic amblyopia , due to a significant uncorrected refractive difference between the two eyes during a critical period of visual development.
  • ➤ most probable diagnosis in this case is amblyopia
  • ➤ anisometropic amblyopia
  • ➤ Ref : KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5 TH EDITION pg.no: 339
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5 TH EDITION pg.no: 339

questions.text: Which of the following types of amblyopia is associated with worst prognosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Stimulus deprivation amblyopia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Anisometropic Amblyopia : This results from unequal refractive errors in the two eyes . Its prognosis is generally good with appropriate corrective lenses and amblyopia therapy, especially if treated early.
  • • Option A
  • • Anisometropic Amblyopia
  • • unequal refractive errors
  • • two eyes
  • • Option B. Strabismic Amblyopia : Caused by misalignment of the eyes (strabismus), this type of amblyopia has a variable prognosis depending on the severity and treatment of the strabismus.
  • • Option B.
  • • Strabismic Amblyopia
  • • misalignment of the eyes
  • • Option D. Meridional Amblyopia: Associated with uncorrected astigmatism, this type of amblyopia has a generally good prognosis with appropriate corrective lenses and amblyopia therapy.
  • • Option D.
  • • Meridional Amblyopia:
  • • uncorrected astigmatism, this type of amblyopia has a generally good prognosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stimulus deprivation amblyopia has the worst prognosis among the types of amblyopia listed, due to the profound impact of visual deprivation during the critical developmental period of the visual system.
  • ➤ Stimulus deprivation amblyopia
  • ➤ worst prognosis
  • ➤ Ref : AAO PAEDIATRIC OPHTHALMOLOGY AND STRABISMUS PAGE 55
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : AAO PAEDIATRIC OPHTHALMOLOGY AND STRABISMUS PAGE 55

questions.text: A patient visits the ophthalmologist with a complaint of inward deviation of the right eye, known as esodeviation. After a thorough evaluation, the ophthalmologist determines that a prism prescription would be beneficial for the patient. What is the ideal orientation or direction in which the prism should be positioned?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Base out

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Base up : Positioning the prism with the base upwards is used to correct hypotropia, where one eye is positioned lower than the other. The light path is deviated upwards, helping to align the lower eye with the other.
  • • Option A.
  • • Base up
  • • prism with the base upwards is used to correct hypotropia,
  • • Option B. Base down : This orientation is used for hypertropia , where one eye is higher than the other. The prism base is positioned downwards, deviating the light path downwards to align the higher eye with the fellow eye.
  • • Option B.
  • • Base down
  • • orientation is used for hypertropia
  • • one eye is higher than the other.
  • • Option D. Base in : The base is positioned towards the nose (medially). This is the correct orientation for correcting exotropia.
  • • Option D.
  • • Base in
  • • positioned towards the nose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For the correction of esotropia , the prism should be positioned with base-out to realign the inward-turned eye outward.
  • ➤ correction of esotropia
  • ➤ prism should be positioned with base-out
  • ➤ realign the inward-turned eye outward.
  • ➤ Ref : Clinical optics by Elkington page 51
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Clinical optics by Elkington page 51

questions.text: What is the given test used in assessment of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Stereopsis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Contrast Sensitivity: This test measures the ability to discern between finer and finer increments of light versus dark (contrast), often using a chart with varying shades of gray or with spatial frequency patterns. Eg. Pelli Robson Chart.
  • • Option A.
  • • Contrast Sensitivity:
  • • ability to discern between finer and finer increments of light versus dark
  • • Option B. Visual Acuity in Children : Various age-appropriate methods are used , such as LEA symbols, Snellen's E chart, or picture chart.
  • • Option B.
  • • Visual Acuity in Children
  • • age-appropriate methods are used
  • • Option D. Malingering : Various techniques are employed , such as the fogging test or the use of duochrome test , to detect exaggeration or feigning of poor vision, often by presenting visual stimuli that are impossible to misinterpret if vision is normal.
  • • Option D.
  • • Malingering
  • • techniques are employed
  • • fogging test or the use of duochrome test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Assessed using tests like the Titmus Fly test or Random Dot Stereogram , which require the patient to wear special glasses and identify 3D shapes from 2D patterns , evaluating depth perception and binocular vision.
  • ➤ Titmus Fly test or Random Dot Stereogram
  • ➤ patient to wear special glasses
  • ➤ identify 3D shapes from 2D patterns
